name: building operation, luxury hotel | building operation, luxury hotel | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/22114/documentation

This dataset represents the operation of a tourist accommodation facility classed as a luxury hotel (comfort category 5stars), located in Campinas, SP, Brazil. It was first opened in 1999 as a brand new resort complex. The complex has capacity to host 1000 people and offers rooms of the following types (total number of rooms is given in brackets): suites with one double bed (453) and suites with two double beds (47). These rooms are distributed among 5 different buildings that are surronded by 7 pools, a gym, a spa, kids area and four conference areas. The laundry is outsourced. The hotel occupies a total area of 58618,2 m2. The average annual occupancy of the hotel is estimated to be 58%, based on Rio de Janeiro's average occupancy for luxury hotels (Source: Anuário Estatístico da Taxa de Ocupação Hoteleira da Cidade do Rio de Janeiro. ABIH-RJ, 2016) which is equal to 211700 guest nights per year. 

This dataset is modelled to represent the service of operating the hotel. It includes: energy and water consumption, furniture and in-room textiles (such as bed linen, bed mattrasses and curtains), electric and electronic equipment used in guest rooms and on hostel premises (including bulbs), cleaning and in-room consumables. Activities include hotel operations and infrastructure based on 1 guest night stay and the lifeframe of the hotel building of 75 years. The case study hotel uses services of an outsourced laundry. To account for its impacts, a separate laundry dataset has been added. The input to the laundry dataset is based on the number of linen pieces sent to laundry by the hotel. The transportation of linen to/from laundry facility was excluded due to data availability. Although the case study hotel has restaurants on site, the inputs of food items have been excluded due to data availability. The energy and water consumption attributed to restaurant operations have been included. Any waste generated in restaurant operations has been included. 


Activities end with guest departure from hotel premises. Due to data availability, the following processes have been excluded: room equipment (lamp, telephone, DVD player, iron, digital clock, in-room safe, door lock), bathroom equipment (showers, mirrors) and kitchen equipment (blender, water filter, iron, deep fryer). Parking is also an outsourced service and, due to unavailable data, it was excluded from this dataset.
category: I:Accommodation and food service activities/55:Accommodation/551:Short term accommodation activities/5510:Short term accommodation activities

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The survey was done in the year 2017 with the data provided covering the operational year 2016-2017.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The hotel is based in Campinas, SP, Brazil
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Technology in use is considered current.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: In terms of operations, energy and water consumption are aggregate and represent the case study hotel as a whole, rather than its specific operational areas (e.g. guest rooms, restaurant and bar). The comments to respective processes explain this in detail.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Primary data from the hotel supplemented with literature-based calculations and estimates, where appropriate.

flow.name: building operation, luxury hotel

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel/lifetime of the product) / (number of guests during the lifetime of the hotel * hotel occupancy rate). Average service life of a television is assumed to be equal to 10 years. Source: Feng and Ma 2009. The energy consumption and environmental impacts of a color TV set in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 17,13-25.

exchanges.description: Calculated value from the total number of linen units used by the hotel. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel/lifetime of the product) / (number of guests during the lifetime of the hotel * hotel occupancy rate). It is assumed that, on average, 4 linen units make 1 kg in weight. Source: Filimonau et al. 2011. Reviewing the carbon footprint analysis of hotels: Life Cycle Energy Analysis (LCEA) as a holistic method for carbon impact appraisal of tourist accommodation. Journal of Cleaner Production, 19, 1917-1930. Assumed average service life is 0.25 years. Source: TRSA 2015. Hospitality Textile Life, Loss and Replacement. Available from: http://www.laundrycompliance.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/trsa-hospitality-hotel-linen-loss.pdf Accessed 16 March 2018. The amount accounts for 10% fabric loss in the cotton textile manufacturing process. Source: Baydar, G., Ciliz, N., and Mammadov, A., 2015. Life cycle assessment of cotton textile products in Turkey. Journal of Cleaner Production, 104(A), 213-223.

exchanges.description: Estimated value. No data on the number of vacuum cleaners in use was provided by the case study hotel. Hence, data from the luxury hotel, Peru, was used as a reference proxy. The Peruvian luxury hotel accounts for 8 vaccum cleaners. As the difference in area between the two hotels is 2.5, it is estimated that the Brazilian luxury hotel accounts for 2.5*8 = 20. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel/lifetime of the product) / (number of guests during the lifetime of the hotel * hotel occupancy rate). Assumed average service life of a vacuum cleaner is 8 years. Source: Gallego-Schmid et al. 2016. Life cycle environmental impacts of vacuum cleaners and the effects of European regulation. Science of the Total Environment, 559, 192-203.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. From the dataset for "cleaning consumables production" GLO 2011-2013, on average cleaning products contain 86% of water. Based on the literature source Golsteijn (2015) the dataset used to represent the water flow is "water, completely softened, at plant", version 2 dataset which corresponds to ecoinvent version 3 dataset "water, completely softened, from decarbonised waterm at user". The amount of water needed is therefore calculated based on the vale of 86% calculated based on Golsteijn (2015) and the amount of cleaning consumable which are expressed as 100% active substance.

Laura Golsteijn, 2015, A compilation of life cycle studies for six household detergent product categories in Europe: the basis for product-specific A.I.S.E. Charter Advanced Sustainability Profiles

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Represents here curtains made of nylon. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel/lifetime of the product) / (number of guests during the lifetime of the hotel * hotel occupancy rate). An average curtain is assumed to have a weight of 5 kg. Source: Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018.  Average service life of a curtain is assumed to be equal to average service life of a carpet which is 10 years. Source: Greenspec 2018. Whole life costing: carpets. Available from: http://www.greenspec.co.uk/building-design/carpets/ Accessed 16 March 2018. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to waste polyethylene.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel) / (number of guests during the lifetime of the hotel * hotel occupancy rate). Combined of all instances of use across the hotel operations. Represents the following cleaning luquids: window cleaner, bleach, washing up liquid, insect killer, pine disinfector, odour eliminator. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to wastewater. As the product "cleaning consumables" is expressed as 100% active substance, the amount of cleaning consumables is multiplied by the average concentration of active substance. According to Golsteijn (2015) the average water content of cleaning consumables is 86.4%, the necessary water input is accounted for with the flow "water, compeltely softened, from decarbonised water, at user". For more information on how the cleaning consumables dataset was created please refer to the relevant dataset in ecoinvent.

2015, Laura Golsteijn, A compilation of life cycle studies for six household detergent product categories in Europe: the basis for product-specific A.I.S.E. Charter Advanced Sustainability Profiles

exchanges.description: Estimated value. Approximated from luxury hotel PE. Given the capacity is 2.5, then the number of bulbs in use = 950*2.5. This represented the amount of input product. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel/lifetime of the product) / (number of guests during the lifetime of the hotel * hotel occupancy rate). Average service life of a bulb is assumed to be equal to 1.1 year. Source: Elijošiutė et al. 2012. Life Cycle Assessment of Compact Fluorescent and Incandescent Lamps: Comparative Analysis. Environmental Research, Engineering and Management, 3(61), 65-72.

exchanges.description: Calculated data. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel) / (number of guests during the lifetime of the hotel * hotel occupancy rate). The amount also includes electricity requirements to produce cotton textile products from raw cotton. It is estimated that 2 MJ of electricity is required to produce 1 kg of cotton textile product. This accounts for 10% fabric loss in the cotton textile manufacturing process. Source: Baydar, G., Ciliz, N., and Mammadov, A., 2015. Life cycle assessment of cotton textile products in Turkey. Journal of Cleaner Production, 104(A), 213-223.

exchanges.description:
Estimated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel/lifetime of the product) / (number of guests during the lifetime of the hotel * hotel occupancy rate). Assumed average service life of all pieces of furniture is 15 years. This represents service life of an average piece of furniture. Source: European Commission 2013. BACKGROUND REPORT. Revision of Ecolabel and Green Public Procurement criteria for the product group Wooden Furniture. September 2013. Available from: http://susproc.jrc.ec.europa.eu/furniture/docs/Background_report_Furniture_September_2013.pdf Accessed 19 March 2018. 
This exchange represents the following: Double bed (unit) is assumed to have a weight of 25 kg, no headboard, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Sofas (unit) Sofa is assumed to have a weight of 37 kg, two seater, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Tables/Desks (unit) Table is assumed to have a weight of 23 kg, medium, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Chairs (unit) Chair is assumed to have a weight of 7 kg, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Wardrobe (unit) is assumed to have a weight of 55 kg (double wardrobe), Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018
